general: This law makes sure that when someone buys a car, they can keep using the same license plate number until they officially transfer ownership of the vehicle. This helps prevent fraud and keeps things organized for both the seller and the buyer. It's like a temporary permit for the new owner to use while they wait for their official paperwork to come through.

* Simplified point 1: The government can make regulations allowing people to keep the registration mark of a vehicle even after it has been transferred to someone else.
* Simplified point 2: This allows the original owner of the vehicle to keep the registration mark if they request it, and can only be exercised once during a time period set by the government.
* Simplified point 3: The definition of "right of retention" in the Vehicle Excise and Registration Act 1994 is updated to reflect this new provision.

summary: The Vehicle Registration Marks Act of 2007 lets the government create rules that let the first owner of a car keep their license plate number even after they sell or give away the car. This can only happen once during a time frame set by the government. This law update helps the original owner keep their license plate number if they want to.
single:
•	The Vehicle Registration Marks Act of 2007 allows the Secretary of State to make regulations that grant a right of retention to a person in whose name a vehicle is registered, or to another person if requested.
•	This right of retention allows the person to have the registration mark assigned to another vehicle that is registered under this Act.
•	The regulations made by the Secretary of State will prescribe the period within which the right of retention can be exercised.
•	The Act also amends section 62(1) of the Vehicle Excise and Registration Act of 1994 to include a definition of "right of retention" as it relates to this Act.
•	The short title of this Act is the Vehicle Registration Marks Act of 2007.
In simpler terms, this Act allows the government to grant a person the right to keep the registration mark of a vehicle even after the vehicle has been transferred to someone else. This right can only be exercised within a certain period of time, as prescribed by the Secretary of State through regulations. This Act also defines a key term, "right of retention," as it relates to this specific legislation.
